thread.title: H.S. girls tennis: State quarterfinal match features plenty of talent
thread.title_full: H.S. girls tennis: State quarterfinal match features plenty of talent

title: H.S. girls tennis: State quarterfinal match features plenty of talent
text:
Print 
Who many feel are the two best girls tennis players in the state will face off today when Paramus Catholic freshman Andrea Cerdan plays Millburn's Stephanie Schrage at the Individual State Championships. 
Paladins coach Ray Zorovich said it's unfortunate, though, that the two will meet in the quarterfinals rather than the finals. 
Schrage, last year's runner-up, was seeded first while Cerdan was seeded fifth despite being higher-ranked than the No. 2, 3 and 4 seeds by the United States Tennis Association. 
"Andrea should've been seeded higher," Zorovich said. "But, the seeding committee never gives enough respect to Bergen County players. I guess they figured Andrea was a freshman so that's where they put her." 
To reach the quarters, Cerdan topped Morristown's Stef Elling and Kinnelon's Brittany Lau in straight sets in rounds 3 and 4 Saturday. 
Zorovich said today's 9 a.m. matchup between Cerdan and Schrage could go either way. 
"They're both very powerful players," Zorovich said. "I think it's going to come down to which one plays the steadiest game. It should be a great match." 
Joining Cerdan in the quarterfinals will be Holy Angels' sixth-seeded freshman Ashley Hess, who lost just six games combined in besting Pennsville's Tori Nugent and Mendham's Lauren Hassell on Saturday. 
"I thought I played really well today," said Hess, who'll face East Brunswick's Jennifer Chen."I'm really excited to make it this far. I'm just going to play my hardest and try to take advantage of the opportunity." 
Two other North Jersey singles players dropped out after Round 3 losses. Holy Angels 18th-seeded senior Adrianne Alfonso lost to No. 20 Cynthia Huang of Newark Academy (6-2, 6-4), while Leonia's unseeded senior Kate Lieber was shut out by Schrage (6-0, 6-0). 
"Honestly, there were some shots [Schrage] made where I wanted to applaud," Lieber said. "She has such a strong game and hit so many winners. 
"I was happy to make it to the third round, though, and getting a chance to play her was great." Â© 2015 North Jersey Media Group Tags:
